JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, DECEMBER 12, 1958

63RD YEAR

AAUP Rates JHU Faculty Salaries
National Newspaper Column Hopkins At 'C'Level
Has Six Million Circulation After Recent Boosts
A total of 90 daily newspapers around the country,
With a combined circulation of more than 6,500,000, this
fall began carrying "From File 7," a wee,kly newspaper
feature column distributed nationally by the Johns Hopkins University.
Patterned after the University's 11-year-old network TV series "Johns Hopkins File 7," the newspaper
column is written and prepared by the University's Public
Relations Office..
Lynn Poole, Director of Public Relations, explained
that this is the first time that any university has offered
such a column on a nationwide
basis. Other universities have
distributed topical material to
newspapers in a regional area,
but never has a general interest
column been written for national
distribution.
Subjects Included
Among the subjects included
In the series so far have been
columns about Dr. John Strong's
balloon experiment, the use of
solar energy in the future, the
trial of John Brown, an interview with Dr. George Carter on
ancient man in America, a discussion of August Piccard's
bathyscope and a feature on
eyesight.
Some of the 90 newspapers
running the column are: Louisville Courier-Journal, Des Moines
-Register and Tribune, Detroit
Free Press, Chicago Daily News,
Los Angeles Sunday Times,
Akron Beacon-Journal, Boston
Globe, "South Bend (Indiana)
Tribune.
Published In 36 States
San Bernardino (California)
Sun-Telegram, Bangor (Maine)
News, New Bedford (Massachusetts) Standard Times, KingsDort (Tennessee) Press, AmarGlobe-Times,
mill°

Niagara Falls Gazette, Salem
(Oregon) Capital Journal,
liuntsville (Ala.) Times, Charleston (S.C.) Evening Post, and
Charlottesville (Va.) Daily
Progress.
The column is being printed
In 36 out of 49 states and also
in the District of Columbia. Six
California papers are publishing
the column; five papers are running it in New Jersey, Texas,

setts; four papers in New York,

Illinois and two papers are
carrying the column in Washington.

Minimum salary schedules for
all full-time members of the
Johns Hopkins Homewood faculty have received a "C" grade
in a recently completed study
conducted by a special sub-committee of-.the American Association of University Professors, it
was learned Wednesday.
Translated into terms of dollars, the rating means that the
minimum paid to a full professor
here is at least $8750; to an associate professor, $6750: to an
assistant professor, $5250; and
to an instructor, $4000.
The AAUP grade for Hopkins
is considerably higher than some
authoritative sources at the University had expected it to be
when the program was first announced in the spring of 1958
(see May 9, 1958, News-Letter,
p. 1, col. 5). At that time, sources
close to the AAUP plan and the
University had opined Johns
Hopkins would receive an "E"
grade.
Recent salary boosts here account for the "C" grade at
Homewood.

And in terms of point five, the
salary rating program is designed to spur institutions to

friends,
alumni, benefactors and legislators, in the case of public institutions, to provide the financial
wherewithal.
Comparative figures for several other institutions have been
mentioned. For example, Harvard minimum salaries have a
rating of "A"; Yale and Princeton have probably already attained an "A" rating or will do
so by February or October of
1959; Haverford salaries have a
"B" grade and Kenyon a "C."
"AA" Grade Rare
Probably only the Institute of
Advanced Studies at Princeton
is now paying "A" grade salaries,
which the AAUP has established
as a goal for all institutions of
higher learning.
Financially, the grade signify
that in an "AA" category a full
professor receives a minimum of
$14,000 per year; and an associate, $10,000.
At the "A" level: full professor, $12,000; associate, $8750;
assistant,
$6750;
instructor,
$5000.

assistant,

$4500.
At the "D" level: full professor, $7500; associate, $6000; assistant, $4750; instructor, $3750.
At the "E"- level: full professor, $6250; associate, $5250; assistant, $4250; instructor, $3500.
And at the "F" level: full professor, $5250; associate, $4500;

dents and the administration: to
make an effort to cut out bad
behavior by anticipation rather
than punishment and to act as a
body to decide on violations and

At Fault
"The Council was at fault in
three areas: for being too quick
to act without set procedures
to guide it; for not sending out
warnings before the Western
Maryland football game on conduct to insure against incidents
and for its anticipation of administrative decisions to a degree where it influenced the
council's.
"It was the general feeling of
the council that too big an issue was made out of the situation and that it was blown up
all out of proportion by the
News-Letter.
"This meeting helped clear the
air between Dr. Morrill and the
council. I feel the experience
gained by this incident will help
the Student Council a great deal
in future situations."

Movies

Due to the fact that many
students who would ordinarily like to see the YMCA
movie "King and I" this evening will be unable to attend
due to the DSRC party tonight, the movie will be shown
tomorrow at 3:55 p.m. and
7:30 p.m. The film will be
shown, as usual, today at 3:55
and 7:30 p.m., with a mixer
following the evening show.

ST. PAUL CLEANERS
Tailoring - Repairing - Dyeing

Still in its formative stages,
the new Hopkins literary magazine has been retitled Venture,
according to editor Niels Sundermeyer.
"At a staff meeting the name
"Scroll" received several objections, so we've decided to rename
it Venture," Sundermeyer explained, adding that "this name
is appropriate because "venture"
is exactly what it will be."
Sundermeyer affirmed that
plans for such a magazine have
received "much favorable comment," and that "a fairly large
number of people have expressed
an interest."
Postponement
According to Sudermeyer, the
first issue will appear "early in
the second term.""We had hoped
to bring it out before Christmas,
but we decided to inaugurate
more elaborate plans than originally anticipated,. and so it will
take some time," he said.
Present plans call for a small,
printed issue which will be available at little or no cost to students. "The main objective is to
present a cross-section of high
quality fiction, poetry and drawing by the students themselves,"
Sundermeyer explained.
Contributions Sought
"At present we are receiving
literary contributions and hope
anyone wishing to submit any
piece of writing will do so soon,"
the Ventureman noted, adding
that "we can be reached through
box 612 or Dr. Macksey of the
Writing Seminars."
Persons willing to collect advertising subscribers are also
needed, Sundermeyer said.

"Even though the world is
now covered by a pale
of darkness, I am confident that
there
Will be a dawn."
These were the words of Dr.
Henry M. Wriston, President of
the Council on
Foreign Relations, as he urged the participants in the Tenth Annual
Student Conference on
United
States Affairs at West Point to
have faith in
progress.
Dr. Wriston, main
speaker at
the
Conference's Banquet last
Friday, recalled other eras when
the -world was
beset with problems and when
the "informed"
believed that progress had ceased
and that the
world had reached
the ultimate
in comfort and
ac
hievement. In each case the

Courage Needed

and be patientcourage to think

be the first to face
grave problems,"
noted Dr. Wriston, who
delivered the Albert
Shaw Memorial
kins in 1923 Lectures at Hopand 1924, and is
the
'U President Emeritus of Brown
niversity.

The graying speaker told the
assembled students and faculty that there were four ways
for a man to negate his education. These would be (1) "to put
your mind in neutral and go as
shoved"; (2) "to let emotions
guide your actions"; (3) "to find
scapegoats for the world's problems. Men do not lead where no
one follows"; and (4) "to equip
yourself with phrases and become a 'name dropper' ... Unthinking repetition of symbols
is a distortion . . . Metaphors
become real .. ."

many colleges and universities

of Hopkins—the University, and not only Hopkins—the
medical school. This television series of long standing
is now joined by a subsidiary propaganda organ, a syndicated newspaper column, which will aid in distributing
the word of Hopkins achievements.

Stile . . . . Heilige

In the past the efforts of the typewriter battery hi
Tiomewood House have been alternately praised and
scorned by this paper. In general, however, they have
produced interesting material which some like to think
encourages young minds of exceptional talent to find
their way to the Homewood.
But there remains much yet to be done before the
nation becomes aware of Hopkins—the University. One
of our number has just returned from a student conference
attended by schools from the entire country where he
grew weary explaining that Hopkins was more than a
medical school situated in the midst of a redevelopment
project, more than a graduate school, which we are told is
revered and unique among universities. ,
Perhaps the greatest service the official Hopkins
organ could .do would be to dispel in some measure this
utter lack of knowledge about the Hopkins. Perhaps
the scholarly research into fields other than medicine
(how many college history students know that the Turner
thesis on the close of the frontier was delivered at Hopkins), our unique athletic program and championship
lacrosse teams, our college life highlighted by June Week
will gain some measure of the publicity they deserve.
We hope that some day a Hopkins man will be able
to venture beyond the Free State and not be beleaguered
by TIIE question, "ya gonna be a doc'tah?" We respect
the medical school, but let's hope that the world will
realize that there is more, much more to the Hopkins.

The Issue—Again!
The Student Council has now added its voice to the
administrative chorus that has seen fit to chastize the
News-Letter for last week's rigamerole.
We can not agree with their assertion that we overplayed the Morrill veto story and still believe we took
the correct staid.
We would point out, however, that the Council's
censure of the News-Letter is directed against our method
of presentation, not our argument and final position.

FOR A.S.M.E. MEETINGS
Just what does a mechanical engineer
do at DuPont? Whether your chosen
field is research, development, design,
production supervision or plant engineering, you'll find many of the
answers to this question in the informative film, Mechanical Engineering
at Du Pont.
From start to finish, this film has
been prepared with the young engineer in mind. Its express purpose is
to show him where he fits into the picture—what kind of assignments he
'hill be called upon to handle in the
chemical industry.
This is a realistic on-the-job film,
without frills and falderal. No professional actors appear in it. All photography was done right in Du Pont
plants and laboratories, and everyone you will see in it is a working
DuPont engineer.
If you would like to learn in considerable detail what mechanical engineers do in the chemical industry,
arrange to see this DuPont film.
Mechanical Engineering at Du Pont
is available at no cost for A.S.M.E.
chapter meetings, fraternity house
and dormitory showings. Write to
Room 12421 Nemours Building, E. I.
du Pont de Nemours & Co. (Inc.),
Wihnington 98, Delaware.

FLASH—Last Wednesday night
the Johns Hopkins basketball
team swamped the Terrors from
Western Maryland 79 to 63. The
Jays jumped to an early lead in
ihe first few moments of play
and kept a steady eight point
margin on the visitors until the
half. At the end of the first half
the home- team had a comfortable 37-26 lead.
During the second half the
spirited Terrors came within
four points of the Jays, but were
never able to break up .the fine
shooting of the Hopkins offense.
Hopkins was able to keep in the
game while two of its regulars,
Dick Weinstein and Bill Berndt,
were kept out of action due to
four personal fouls each. High
scorers for Hopkins were Larry
Becker with 23 points and Bill
DeVoe with 15 points.
The Blue Jay basketballers
face a busy week with three
league contests crammed into

the next seven days. Tomorrow
night the men from Homewood
travel to Pennsylvania for a
Middle Atlantic Conference tilt
with Haverford, as they seek
vengeance for a 71-66 trouncing
at the hands of the 'Fords last
season.

Large Mat Turnout
Gives Jays Balance
"A pick-up schedule next year;
and that only if we have enough
men .out to warrant forming a
team, is our outlook for the nearfuture so far as wrestling at
Hopkins is concerned." This was
Coach Mickey Cochrane's corn.:
ment on the status of the mat
sport at Homewood for the next
two seasons, given in .an interview last week.

High man for the Jays was
Billy Morrill returning after a
year's absence from court action,
with 19 points, closely followed
by Dick Weinstein, with 16, and
Billy DeVoe, with 15 markers.
Morrill scored 15 of his points in
the torrid second half, a 44 point
scoring spree for the -Hopkins
hoopsters. Dick Weinstein and
Billy Berndt were high on both
backboards all evening, consistently snaring rebounds for the
Blue Jay five.

Next Monday night the Jays
return home to host Delaware
U. in another tussle, while on
Thursday the Blue close out their
pre-Christmas skirmishing with
another loop contest, this time
with the Garnets of Swarthmore.

The Hopkins varsity hoopsters practice for tomorrow's encounter with Middle Atlantic Conference opponent Haverford (left, right). Led by Billy Morrill and Dick Weinstein (center) the
Jays opened their season with a strong 82-58 victory over Towson State Teachers last week. The
men in Blue engage in three contests in this final week of pre-holiday action.

.
Margin Increased
Once again, the Teachers
closed the gap, shortening the
Hopkins advantage to 26-22;
but Dick Weinstein and Chuck
Loughran hit on quick field goals
to increase the margin to 30-22.
Closing out the half, Eden sank
two shots for Towson, while
Berndt and DeVoe hit-two apiece
for the Jays, putting the intermission mark at 38-26. .
In the second half, the Teachers managed to cut the margin
to 43-33, but hot shooting by
Morill and other Jays pushed
the lead to 51-33. From that
point on it was all Hopkins as
Weinstein, Morrill, and Company
increased the score up to the
final gun, the final count being
82-58, Blue Jays.

The Applied Physics Laboratory of the Johns Hopkins University has awarded a $1,000,000
contract to John McShane, Inc.,
for construction of a 42,000
square foot addition to its
facilities.

building. The air-conditioned
building will include laboratories,
a storage vault and conference
rooms, and will feature a reinforced roof to accomodate heavy
equipment for outside research
and development.

Included in the new construction will be new laboratory space
and an addition to the cafeteria.
The new building will be the second addition since 1954 to the
Physics Lab, located off Route 29
in Clarksville, Howard County.

The Applied Physics Laboratory was .established in 1942 to
develop a proximity fuse for
artillery shells. The development
of this fuse has been described
as one of the outstanding
achievements of World War II.
Since 1945 the Laboratory has
been engaged in guided missile
development for the Navy Bureau
of Ordnance. Dr. R. E. Gibson is
director of the Laboratory.

Planned by the New York firm
of Voorhees, Walker, Smith, and
Smith, the new structure will
incorporate the latest features

AAUP Rates JHU Faculty Salaries
National Newspaper Column Hopkins At 'C'Level
Has Six Million Circulation After Recent Boosts
A total of 90 daily newspapers around the country,
With a combined circulation of more than 6,500,000, this
fall began carrying "From File 7," a wee,kly newspaper
feature column distributed nationally by the Johns Hopkins University.
Patterned after the University's 11-year-old network TV series "Johns Hopkins File 7," the newspaper
column is written and prepared by the University's Public
Relations Office..
Lynn Poole, Director of Public Relations, explained
that this is the first time that any university has offered
such a column on a nationwide
basis. Other universities have
distributed topical material to
newspapers in a regional area,
but never has a general interest
column been written for national
distribution.
Subjects Included
Among the subjects included
In the series so far have been
columns about Dr. John Strong's
balloon experiment, the use of
solar energy in the future, the
trial of John Brown, an interview with Dr. George Carter on
ancient man in America, a discussion of August Piccard's
bathyscope and a feature on
eyesight.
Some of the 90 newspapers
running the column are: Louisville Courier-Journal, Des Moines
-Register and Tribune, Detroit
Free Press, Chicago Daily News,
Los Angeles Sunday Times,
Akron Beacon-Journal, Boston
Globe, "South Bend (Indiana)
Tribune.
Published In 36 States
San Bernardino (California)
Sun-Telegram, Bangor (Maine)
News, New Bedford (Massachusetts) Standard Times, KingsDort (Tennessee) Press, AmarGlobe-Times,
mill°
(Texas)
Niagara Falls Gazette, Salem
(Oregon) Capital Journal,
liuntsville (Ala.) Times, Charleston (S.C.) Evening Post, and
Charlottesville (Va.) Daily
Progress.
The column is being printed
In 36 out of 49 states and also
in the District of Columbia. Six
California papers are publishing
the column; five papers are running it in New Jersey, Texas,
MassachuPennsylvania and
setts; four papers in New York,
South Carolina, Wisconsin and
Illinois and two papers are
carrying the column in Washington.

Minimum salary schedules for
all full-time members of the
Johns Hopkins Homewood faculty have received a "C" grade
in a recently completed study
conducted by a special sub-committee of-.the American Association of University Professors, it
was learned Wednesday.
Translated into terms of dollars, the rating means that the
minimum paid to a full professor
here is at least $8750; to an associate professor, $6750: to an
assistant professor, $5250; and
to an instructor, $4000.
The AAUP grade for Hopkins
is considerably higher than some
authoritative sources at the University had expected it to be
when the program was first announced in the spring of 1958
(see May 9, 1958, News-Letter,
p. 1, col. 5). At that time, sources
close to the AAUP plan and the
University had opined Johns
Hopkins would receive an "E"
grade.
Recent salary boosts here account for the "C" grade at
Homewood.

Still in its formative stages,
the new Hopkins literary magazine has been retitled Venture,
according to editor Niels Sundermeyer.
"At a staff meeting the name
"Scroll" received several objections, so we've decided to rename
it Venture," Sundermeyer explained, adding that "this name
is appropriate because "venture"
is exactly what it will be."
Sundermeyer affirmed that
plans for such a magazine have
received "much favorable comment," and that "a fairly large
number of people have expressed
an interest."
Postponement
According to Sudermeyer, the
first issue will appear "early in
the second term.""We had hoped
to bring it out before Christmas,
but we decided to inaugurate
more elaborate plans than originally anticipated,. and so it will
take some time," he said.
Present plans call for a small,
printed issue which will be available at little or no cost to students. "The main objective is to
present a cross-section of high
quality fiction, poetry and drawing by the students themselves,"
Sundermeyer explained.
Contributions Sought
"At present we are receiving
literary contributions and hope
anyone wishing to submit any
piece of writing will do so soon,"
the Ventureman noted, adding
that "we can be reached through
box 612 or Dr. Macksey of the
Writing Seminars."
Persons willing to collect advertising subscribers are also
needed, Sundermeyer said.

of Hopkins—the University, and not only Hopkins—the
medical school. This television series of long standing
is now joined by a subsidiary propaganda organ, a syndicated newspaper column, which will aid in distributing
the word of Hopkins achievements.

Stile . . . . Heilige

In the past the efforts of the typewriter battery hi
Tiomewood House have been alternately praised and
scorned by this paper. In general, however, they have
produced interesting material which some like to think
encourages young minds of exceptional talent to find
their way to the Homewood.
But there remains much yet to be done before the
nation becomes aware of Hopkins—the University. One
of our number has just returned from a student conference
attended by schools from the entire country where he
grew weary explaining that Hopkins was more than a
medical school situated in the midst of a redevelopment
project, more than a graduate school, which we are told is
revered and unique among universities. ,
Perhaps the greatest service the official Hopkins
organ could .do would be to dispel in some measure this
utter lack of knowledge about the Hopkins. Perhaps
the scholarly research into fields other than medicine
(how many college history students know that the Turner
thesis on the close of the frontier was delivered at Hopkins), our unique athletic program and championship
lacrosse teams, our college life highlighted by June Week
will gain some measure of the publicity they deserve.
We hope that some day a Hopkins man will be able
to venture beyond the Free State and not be beleaguered
by TIIE question, "ya gonna be a doc'tah?" We respect
the medical school, but let's hope that the world will
realize that there is more, much more to the Hopkins.

The Issue—Again!
The Student Council has now added its voice to the
administrative chorus that has seen fit to chastize the
News-Letter for last week's rigamerole.
We can not agree with their assertion that we overplayed the Morrill veto story and still believe we took
the correct staid.
We would point out, however, that the Council's
censure of the News-Letter is directed against our method
of presentation, not our argument and final position.

FLASH—Last Wednesday night
the Johns Hopkins basketball
team swamped the Terrors from
Western Maryland 79 to 63. The
Jays jumped to an early lead in
ihe first few moments of play
and kept a steady eight point
margin on the visitors until the
half. At the end of the first half
the home- team had a comfortable 37-26 lead.
During the second half the
spirited Terrors came within
four points of the Jays, but were
never able to break up .the fine
shooting of the Hopkins offense.
Hopkins was able to keep in the
game while two of its regulars,
Dick Weinstein and Bill Berndt,
were kept out of action due to
four personal fouls each. High
scorers for Hopkins were Larry
Becker with 23 points and Bill
DeVoe with 15 points.
The Blue Jay basketballers
face a busy week with three
league contests crammed into

the next seven days. Tomorrow
night the men from Homewood
travel to Pennsylvania for a
Middle Atlantic Conference tilt
with Haverford, as they seek
vengeance for a 71-66 trouncing
at the hands of the 'Fords last
season.

Large Mat Turnout
Gives Jays Balance

and that only if we have enough

ment on the status of the mat
sport at Homewood for the next
two seasons, given in .an interview last week.

Billy Morrill returning after a
year's absence from court action,
with 19 points, closely followed
by Dick Weinstein, with 16, and
Billy DeVoe, with 15 markers.

the torrid second half, a 44 point
scoring spree for the -Hopkins
hoopsters. Dick Weinstein and
Billy Berndt were high on both
backboards all evening, consistently snaring rebounds for the
Blue Jay five.

Next Monday night the Jays
return home to host Delaware
U. in another tussle, while on
Thursday the Blue close out their
pre-Christmas skirmishing with
another loop contest, this time
with the Garnets of Swarthmore.

The Hopkins varsity hoopsters practice for tomorrow's encounter with Middle Atlantic Conference opponent Haverford (left, right). Led by Billy Morrill and Dick Weinstein (center) the
Jays opened their season with a strong 82-58 victory over Towson State Teachers last week. The
men in Blue engage in three contests in this final week of pre-holiday action.

.
Margin Increased
Once again, the Teachers
closed the gap, shortening the
Hopkins advantage to 26-22;
but Dick Weinstein and Chuck
Loughran hit on quick field goals
to increase the margin to 30-22.
Closing out the half, Eden sank
two shots for Towson, while
Berndt and DeVoe hit-two apiece
for the Jays, putting the intermission mark at 38-26. .
In the second half, the Teachers managed to cut the margin
to 43-33, but hot shooting by
Morill and other Jays pushed
the lead to 51-33. From that
point on it was all Hopkins as
Weinstein, Morrill, and Company
increased the score up to the
final gun, the final count being
82-58, Blue Jays.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DEC. 12, 1951

Applied Physics Lab Hopkins Host For Universities
Awards Monster Bid In Invitational Debate Tourney
The Applied Physics Laboratory of the Johns Hopkins University has awarded a $1,000,000
contract to John McShane, Inc.,
for construction of a 42,000
square foot addition to its
facilities.

building. The air-conditioned
building will include laboratories,
a storage vault and conference
rooms, and will feature a reinforced roof to accomodate heavy
equipment for outside research
and development.

Included in the new construction will be new laboratory space
and an addition to the cafeteria.
The new building will be the second addition since 1954 to the
Physics Lab, located off Route 29
in Clarksville, Howard County.

The Applied Physics Laboratory was .established in 1942 to
develop a proximity fuse for
artillery shells. The development
of this fuse has been described
as one of the outstanding
achievements of World War II.
Since 1945 the Laboratory has
been engaged in guided missile
development for the Navy Bureau
of Ordnance. Dr. R. E. Gibson is
director of the Laboratory.

Planned by the New York firm
of Voorhees, Walker, Smith, and
Smith, the new structure will
incorporate the latest features
of a modern laboratory and office
